context.text: Spletzer et al. recently reported the use of this approach for detecting small changes in mass in an array of mechanically coupled microcantilevers and showed that the shifts in eigenstates could be as high as two to three orders of magnitude greater than the resonant-frequency variations induced by the same perturbation in mass in a single cantilever of the same dimensions as one of the coupled structures [13], [14].
In this paper, unlike the previous attempts in [13] and [14], we use the phenomenon of mode localization as a method of detecting small perturbations in stiffness.

In contrast to prior works [13], [14], variations in eigenstates are studied by electrically coupling the two structures, as this allows for significantly weaker coupling-spring constants than those that can be attained mechanically and, in consequence, the possibility of greater variations in vibration modes for a given stiffness perturbation.

context.text: In this paper, the modified subspace-based optimization method compares with the original CSI method [1], [2], one of its variants [13], and a particular source-type integral-equation (STIE) method [14].

Initial step, \$n = 0\$: \$\overline{\overline{\xi}}_{0}\$ is obtained from the back propagation [1]–[3], [13]; \$\overline{\alpha}_{p, 0}^{n} = 0\$; initialize the search direction \$\overline{\rho}_{p, 0} = 0\$.

Update \$\overline{\alpha}_{p, n}^{n}\$: Calculate gradient (Frechet derivative) \$\overline{g}_{p, n} = \nabla_{\overline{\alpha}_{p}^{n}}f\$ evaluated at \$\overline{\alpha}^{n}_{p, n - 1}\$ and \$\overline{\overline{\xi}}_{n - 1}\$; determine the Polak–Ribiere CG search directions \$\overline{\rho}_{p, n} = \overline{g}_{p, n} + ({\rm Re}[(\overline{g}_{p, n} - \overline{g}_{p, n - 1})^{\ast} \cdot \overline{g}_{p, n}]/ \Vert\overline{g}_{p, n - 1}\Vert^{2})\overline{\rho}_{p, n - 1}\$ [2], [3], [13].
The objective function becomes quadratic in terms of parameter \$d_{p, n}\$, and \$d_{p, n}\$ can be easily obtained as done in [1]–[3], and [13].

For a better comparison between the modified subspace-based optimization method and the CSI method, we use the same notion adopted in Section II, which is slightly different from that in the CSI papers [1]–[3], [13].

Initial step, \$n = 0\$: \$\overline{\overline{\xi}}_{0}\$ and \$\overline{I}_{p, 0}^{d}\$ are obtained from the back propagation [1]–[3], [13]; for the purpose of solving for \$\overline{I}_{p}^{d}\$, initialize the search direction \$\overline{\rho}_{p, 0}^{I} = 0\$; for the purpose of solving for \$\overline{\overline{\xi}}\$, initialize the search direction \$\overline{\rho}_{p, 0}^{\xi} = 0\$.
However, as noted in later versions of CSI methods [2], [13], it is not certain whether this choice will monotonically reduce the error in the second term of (13).
It is worth comparing the modified subspace-based optimization method with the variant version of CSI proposed in [13].

The CSI in [13] assumes that a part of contrast and contrast source are both known a priori, and then, unknown parts of contrast and contrast source are reconstructed using the traditional CSI [2] method.
Although the modified subspace-based optimization method is close in format to the CSI in [13] method, there are two significant differences between them.

First, the CSI in [13] method assumes that a part of contrast is known a priori, and normally, such a priori information can be obtained from another measurement or from the same measurement using a simple (linear) inversion method [13].
The total number of unknowns in the CSI in [13] is \$N_{i}M + M\$, whereas it is \$N_{i}(M - L) + M\$ in the modified subspace-based optimization method.

context.text: The total electric field incident upon the \$m\$th subunit is denoted as \${\bf E}^{\rm tot}({\bf r}_{m})\$, and they satisfy the following self-consistent equation, which is known as the coupled-dipole method (CDM) or discrete dipole approximation (DDA) [15], [16]: where \$k\$ is the free-space wavenumber, \$\eta_{0}\$ is the impedance of the free space, \$g({\bf r}_{m}, {\bf r}_{n})\$ denotes the 2-D free-space Green's function, and the polarization strength \$\xi_{n}\$ relates the contrast displacement current \${\bf I}^{d}({\bf r}_{n})\$ induced in the \$n\$th subunit to the total incident electric field \${\bf E}^{\rm tot}({\bf r}_{n})\$ by The scattering strength is given by \$\xi_{n} = -i(k/\eta_{0}) A_{n} [\epsilon_{r}({\bf r}_{n}) - 1]\$, where \$\epsilon_{\bf r}({\bf r}_{n})\$ and \$A_{n}\$ denote the relative permittivity and the area of the \$n\$th subunit, respectively.
The numerical method used in the CSI [1], [2] is a kind of Method of Moment (MoM) [21], whereas the modified subspace-based optimization method uses the CDM (or DDA) method [15], [16].

However, these features, for more than three levels, are achieved at the expense of the divergence of dc capacitor voltages, resulting in the collapse of some and rise of others due to the nonuniform power drawn from them [1]–[3], [8]–[18], [23]–[38].
Therefore, balancing of the dc capacitor voltages is required under all conditions, which determines both the safety and efficiency of DCMLIs [1]–[3].
Therefore, extra capacitor voltage control circuits are preferably used in practice [1], [2], [7]–[15].
The other structural and operational details of the inverter can be found in [1]–[4] and [22].

However, in a steady-state operation of DCMLI, the voltages of \$C_{d1}\$ and \$C_{d4}\$ always tend to increase while those of \$C_{d2}\$ and \$C_{d3}\$ tend to decrease [1]–[3], [8]–[18], [23]–[38].
The multilevel technique solves the problems of static and dynamic sharing of the voltage and limits the \$dv/dt\$ to standard levels [1]–[4], [39], [40].
Similarly, the four-level chopper circuit in Fig. 2(b) resembles that of a single-leg four-level flying-capacitor inverter [1]–[3].
The phase disposition modulation strategy (described in [1]–[3] and [42]–[44]) is considered with an amplitude modulation index \$(m_{a}) = 0.8\$ and a frequency modulation index \$(m_{f}) = 21\$.

references.text: Y. Shakweh, "MV inverter stack topologies", Power Eng. J., vol. 15, no. 3, pp. 139-149, Jun. 2001.
references.title: MV inverter stack topologies

context.text: Among The multilevel voltage-source-inverter configurations, the diode-clamped multilevel inverter (DCMLI) is widely accepted for applications in high-power drives and utility systems [1]–[2][22].

It possesses some of the desirable features like the following: 1) the dc capacitors can be easily precharged as a group; 2) switching control is easiest; and 3) the protection circuit required is least complex among the multilevel inverters, etc. [1]–[2][7].

However, these features, for more than three levels, are achieved at the expense of the divergence of dc capacitor voltages, resulting in the collapse of some and rise of others due to the nonuniform power drawn from them [1]–[2][3], [8]–[18], [23]–[38].
Therefore, balancing of the dc capacitor voltages is required under all conditions, which determines both the safety and efficiency of DCMLIs [1]–[2][3].
Therefore, extra capacitor voltage control circuits are preferably used in practice [1], [2], [7]–[15].
The other structural and operational details of the inverter can be found in [1]–[2][4] and [22].

However, in a steady-state operation of DCMLI, the voltages of \$C_{d1}\$ and \$C_{d4}\$ always tend to increase while those of \$C_{d2}\$ and \$C_{d3}\$ tend to decrease [1]–[2][3], [8]–[18], [23]–[38].
The multilevel technique solves the problems of static and dynamic sharing of the voltage and limits the \$dv/dt\$ to standard levels [1]–[2][4], [39], [40].
Similarly, the four-level chopper circuit in Fig. 2(b) resembles that of a single-leg four-level flying-capacitor inverter [1]–[2][3].

Apart from the aforementioned advantages, since the flying-capacitor-based chopper has a multilevel configuration, it is expected to have more advantages like reduced electromagnetic compatibility problems and lower acoustic noise due to reduced \$dv/dt\$, limited voltage transients, etc. [1]–[2][5].
The phase disposition modulation strategy (described in [1]–[2][3] and [42]–[44]) is considered with an amplitude modulation index \$(m_{a}) = 0.8\$ and a frequency modulation index \$(m_{f}) = 21\$.

references.text: L. G. Franquelo, J. Rodrguez, J. I. Leon, S. Kouro, R. Portillo and M. A. M. Prats, "The age of multilevel converters arrives", IEEE Ind. Electron. Mag., vol. 2, no. 2, pp. 28-39, Jun. 2008.
references.title: The age of multilevel converters arrives

context.text: Among The multilevel voltage-source-inverter configurations, the diode-clamped multilevel inverter (DCMLI) is widely accepted for applications in high-power drives and utility systems [1]–[4][22].

It possesses some of the desirable features like the following: 1) the dc capacitors can be easily precharged as a group; 2) switching control is easiest; and 3) the protection circuit required is least complex among the multilevel inverters, etc. [1]–[4][7].
The other structural and operational details of the inverter can be found in [1]–[4] and [22].

As stated earlier, the dc capacitors in DCMLI suffer from voltage imbalance as the currents \$i_{2}\$ and \$i_{4}\$ have nonzero average values [Fig. 1(a)] under most of the practical conditions [4]–[21].
Therefore, this solution is not preferred for many applications [4], [39], [40].
The multilevel technique solves the problems of static and dynamic sharing of the voltage and limits the \$dv/dt\$ to standard levels [1]–[4], [39], [40].

Apart from the aforementioned advantages, since the flying-capacitor-based chopper has a multilevel configuration, it is expected to have more advantages like reduced electromagnetic compatibility problems and lower acoustic noise due to reduced \$dv/dt\$, limited voltage transients, etc. [1]–[4][5].

context.text: Among The multilevel voltage-source-inverter configurations, the diode-clamped multilevel inverter (DCMLI) is widely accepted for applications in high-power drives and utility systems [1]–[8][22].

However, these features, for more than three levels, are achieved at the expense of the divergence of dc capacitor voltages, resulting in the collapse of some and rise of others due to the nonuniform power drawn from them [1]–[3], [8]–[18], [23]–[38].

Two possible solutions of the voltage imbalance problem exist: 1) installing of voltage-balancing circuits on the dc side of the inverter [8]–[16], [23]–[25] and 2) modifying the converter switching pattern according to a control strategy [17], [18], [26]–[38].
However, voltage balancing would influence reactive power control if priority were given to voltage balancing [8].
Therefore, extra capacitor voltage control circuits are preferably used in practice [1], [2], [7]–[8][15].

There are many articles available in literature discussing the extra control circuits for dc capacitor voltage balancing in DCMLIs, which are mostly bidirectional buck–boost choppers [8]–[16], [23]–[25].
In [8]–[12], such circuits are successfully tested when DCMLI is used for STATCOM applications.

As stated earlier, the dc capacitors in DCMLI suffer from voltage imbalance as the currents \$i_{2}\$ and \$i_{4}\$ have nonzero average values [Fig. 1(a)] under most of the practical conditions [4]–[8][21].
To prevent this, a chopper circuit like that shown in Fig. 1(b) is used conventionally [8]–[16], [23]–[25].

However, in a steady-state operation of DCMLI, the voltages of \$C_{d1}\$ and \$C_{d4}\$ always tend to increase while those of \$C_{d2}\$ and \$C_{d3}\$ tend to decrease [1]–[3], [8]–[18], [23]–[38].
There are many schemes available in the literature for controlling the chopper in Fig. 1(b) [8]–[15], [28].
The detailed operating principles of this chopper and different control schemes can be found in [8]–[16], [22], and [23].

references.text: A. Shukla, A. Ghosh and A. Joshi, "Control schemes for DC capacitor voltages equalization in diode-clamped multilevel inverter-based DSTATCOM", IEEE Trans. Power Del., vol. 23, no. 2, pp. 1139-1149, Apr. 2008.
references.title:
Control schemes for DC capacitor voltages equalization in diode-clamped multilevel inverter-based 
DSTATCOM

context.text: Among The multilevel voltage-source-inverter configurations, the diode-clamped multilevel inverter (DCMLI) is widely accepted for applications in high-power drives and utility systems [1]–[10][22].

However, these features, for more than three levels, are achieved at the expense of the divergence of dc capacitor voltages, resulting in the collapse of some and rise of others due to the nonuniform power drawn from them [1]–[3], [8]–[10][18], [23]–[38].

Two possible solutions of the voltage imbalance problem exist: 1) installing of voltage-balancing circuits on the dc side of the inverter [8]–[10][16], [23]–[25] and 2) modifying the converter switching pattern according to a control strategy [17], [18], [26]–[38].

It is also to be noted that, for applications like a unified power flow controller (UPFC), where two such converters are connected back to back, the switching modification strategy necessitates the two converters to operate at a fixed ac voltage ratio for the capacitor voltage equalization [10].
Therefore, extra capacitor voltage control circuits are preferably used in practice [1], [2], [7]–[10][15].

There are many articles available in literature discussing the extra control circuits for dc capacitor voltage balancing in DCMLIs, which are mostly bidirectional buck–boost choppers [8]–[10][16], [23]–[25].
In [8]–[10][12], such circuits are successfully tested when DCMLI is used for STATCOM applications.

As stated earlier, the dc capacitors in DCMLI suffer from voltage imbalance as the currents \$i_{2}\$ and \$i_{4}\$ have nonzero average values [Fig. 1(a)] under most of the practical conditions [4]–[10][21].
To prevent this, a chopper circuit like that shown in Fig. 1(b) is used conventionally [8]–[10][16], [23]–[25].

However, in a steady-state operation of DCMLI, the voltages of \$C_{d1}\$ and \$C_{d4}\$ always tend to increase while those of \$C_{d2}\$ and \$C_{d3}\$ tend to decrease [1]–[3], [8]–[10][18], [23]–[38].
There are many schemes available in the literature for controlling the chopper in Fig. 1(b) [8]–[10][15], [28].
The detailed operating principles of this chopper and different control schemes can be found in [8]–[10][16], [22], and [23].

references.text: A. Shukla, A. Ghosh and A. Joshi, "State feedback control of multilevel inverters for DSTATCOM applications", IEEE Trans. Power Del., vol. 22, no. 4, pp. 2409-2418, Oct. 2007.
references.title: State feedback control of multilevel inverters for DSTATCOM applications

context.text: Among The multilevel voltage-source-inverter configurations, the diode-clamped multilevel inverter (DCMLI) is widely accepted for applications in high-power drives and utility systems [1]–[13][22].

However, these features, for more than three levels, are achieved at the expense of the divergence of dc capacitor voltages, resulting in the collapse of some and rise of others due to the nonuniform power drawn from them [1]–[3], [8]–[13][18], [23]–[38].

There are many articles available in literature discussing the extra control circuits for dc capacitor voltage balancing in DCMLIs, which are mostly bidirectional buck–boost choppers [8]–[13][16], [23]–[25].

To prevent this, a chopper circuit like that shown in Fig. 1(b) is used conventionally [8]–[13][16], [23]–[25].

context.text: Among The multilevel voltage-source-inverter configurations, the diode-clamped multilevel inverter (DCMLI) is widely accepted for applications in high-power drives and utility systems [1]–[15][22].

However, these features, for more than three levels, are achieved at the expense of the divergence of dc capacitor voltages, resulting in the collapse of some and rise of others due to the nonuniform power drawn from them [1]–[3], [8]–[15][18], [23]–[38].

Two possible solutions of the voltage imbalance problem exist: 1) installing of voltage-balancing circuits on the dc side of the inverter [8]–[15][16], [23]–[25] and 2) modifying the converter switching pattern according to a control strategy [17], [18], [26]–[38].
Therefore, extra capacitor voltage control circuits are preferably used in practice [1], [2], [7]–[15].

There are many articles available in literature discussing the extra control circuits for dc capacitor voltage balancing in DCMLIs, which are mostly bidirectional buck–boost choppers [8]–[15][16], [23]–[25].

The performance of the back-to-back-connected five-level diode-clamped converters supported by a pair of buck–boost choppers for dc capacitor voltage balancing is found to be effective as well [15], [16].

As stated earlier, the dc capacitors in DCMLI suffer from voltage imbalance as the currents \$i_{2}\$ and \$i_{4}\$ have nonzero average values [Fig. 1(a)] under most of the practical conditions [4]–[15][21].
To prevent this, a chopper circuit like that shown in Fig. 1(b) is used conventionally [8]–[15][16], [23]–[25].

However, in a steady-state operation of DCMLI, the voltages of \$C_{d1}\$ and \$C_{d4}\$ always tend to increase while those of \$C_{d2}\$ and \$C_{d3}\$ tend to decrease [1]–[3], [8]–[15][18], [23]–[38].
There are many schemes available in the literature for controlling the chopper in Fig. 1(b) [8]–[15], [28].
The detailed operating principles of this chopper and different control schemes can be found in [8]–[15][16], [22], and [23].

context.text: Recently, it has been shown that the fuzzy-model-based representation that was proposed by Takagi and Sugeno [1], which is known as the T–S fuzzy model, is a successful approach to deal with the nonlinear control systems, and there are many successful applications of the T–S fuzzy-model-based approach to the nonlinear control systems (see [2]–[23] and references therein).

All the aforementioned works regarding successful applications of the T–S fuzzy-model-based approach (see [2]–[23] and references therein) are, under the assumption that the nominal T–S fuzzy-model-based control systems are locally controllable (i.e., each fuzzy rule of the nominal T–S fuzzy-model-based control systems has a full row rank for its controllability matrix), to design the fuzzy parallel-distributed-compensation (PDC) controllers.

However, here, it should be noticed that although the PDC controller of each control rule can control every state variable in the corresponding rule under the presented conditions in (8) being held, the PDC controller gains should be determined using global design criteria that are needed to guarantee the global stability and control performance [4], where many useful global design criteria have been proposed by some researchers in the literatures (see, for example, [2]–[9], [12], [13], [17], and [23] and references therein).

All the aforementioned works regarding successful applications of the T–S fuzzy-model-based approach (see [2]–[4][23] and references therein) are, under the assumption that the nominal T–S fuzzy-model-based control systems are locally controllable (i.e., each fuzzy rule of the nominal T–S fuzzy-model-based control systems has a full row rank for its controllability matrix), to design the fuzzy parallel-distributed-compensation (PDC) controllers.

Based on the approach of using the sector nonlinearity in the fuzzy model construction, both the fuzzy set of the premise part and the linear uncertain dynamic model of the consequent part in the exact T–S fuzzy control model with parametric uncertainties can be derived from the given nonlinear uncertain control model [4].

context.text: Recently, it has been shown that the fuzzy-model-based representation that was proposed by Takagi and Sugeno [1], which is known as the T–S fuzzy model, is a successful approach to deal with the nonlinear control systems, and there are many successful applications of the T–S fuzzy-model-based approach to the nonlinear control systems (see [2]–[5][23] and references therein).

All the aforementioned works regarding successful applications of the T–S fuzzy-model-based approach (see [2]–[5][23] and references therein) are, under the assumption that the nominal T–S fuzzy-model-based control systems are locally controllable (i.e., each fuzzy rule of the nominal T–S fuzzy-model-based control systems has a full row rank for its controllability matrix), to design the fuzzy parallel-distributed-compensation (PDC) controllers.

However, here, it should be noticed that although the PDC controller of each control rule can control every state variable in the corresponding rule under the presented conditions in (8) being held, the PDC controller gains should be determined using global design criteria that are needed to guarantee the global stability and control performance [4], where many useful global design criteria have been proposed by some researchers in the literatures (see, for example, [2]–[5][9], [12], [13], [17], and [23] and references therein).

context.text: It is also shown that the RBFN can fit an arbitrary function with just one hidden layer [10], [11].

It was shown in [10] that an RBFN and a fuzzy system are equivalent under the following conditions.

1
The number of centers of RBFN is equal to the number of fuzzy rules.

2
The output of each rule is a constant.

3
The fuzzy set membership functions within each rule are Gaussian with the same variance.

4
The fuzzy composition of conjunctive antecedents of each rule is multiplication.

5
Both the RBFN and fuzzy system use the same method to derive the final output, i.e., weighted average.

context.text: Transient-signal-excitation approaches [10], [18], [19] or methods exploiting transient voltage changes within the space-vector pulsewidth modulation (PWM) [1], [2], [5] use the machine current reaction to determine the saliency information, which is the basic principle for sensorless control.

In recent years, several new signal-injection-based approaches that integrate the \$di/dt\$ measurements within the fundamental space-vector PWM (SVPWM) sequence have been presented [1]–[6], [18], [19].

To guarantee a minimum pulse duration, which is necessary for a current-slope measurement in [1], [5], [18], and [19], SVPWM is modified by introducing additional compensating switching states with inverse direction.
The basic principle of integrating fundamental-wave excitation and transient excitation is not completely new [1], [3], [4].
However, in [1], [3], and [4] all three switching states (two active states and the zero vector) are exploited for the detection of the saliencies.
If the reference voltage is lying very close to the border of one of the sectors, there is too little time for an accurate current-slope measurement [1], [2].
The real-time processing requirements can be compared to the methods in [1], [2], and [10].
The methods proposed in this paper, as well as that in [1], have increased requirements.
Not many details are given about this in [1] and [5].
In [1] and [5], this elimination is realized by combining two different active or a combination between active and inactive switching states, which slightly increases complexity.
In [1] and [5], open-slot machines with clear dominating slotting saliency are used, wherein the influence of the mean inductance change is negligible compared to the position signal.

context.text: In high-frequency and high-power converters, it is desirable to use insulated-gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs) for primary switches and to utilize soft-switching techniques such as zero-voltage switching (ZVS) and zero-current switching (ZCS) [1]–[24].
In high-frequency converters, soft-switching techniques are widely used to reduce the switching loss that results from high switching frequency [1]–[33].

In many proposed techniques for high-frequency and high-power conversions, zero-voltage- and zero-current-switching (ZVZCS) full-bridge (FB) PWM converters [1], [6]–[13], [25]–[29], which are driven by phase-shifted pulsewidth-modulation control, are most desirable because IGBTs can be applied with reduced switching loss.

Among previous soft-switching FB converters, a series-resonant converter (SRC) [14]–[21] is the simplest topology.

context.text: In high-frequency converters, soft-switching techniques are widely used to reduce the switching loss that results from high switching frequency [1]–[25][33].

In many proposed techniques for high-frequency and high-power conversions, zero-voltage- and zero-current-switching (ZVZCS) full-bridge (FB) PWM converters [1], [6]–[13], [25]–[29], which are driven by phase-shifted pulsewidth-modulation control, are most desirable because IGBTs can be applied with reduced switching loss.

By employing auxiliary switches or circuits, such as a secondary passive snubber [12], a secondary active clamp [6], [10], or a saturable inductor and a dc blocking capacitor [25], the primary current during the freewheeling period is reset.

On the other hand, in the proposed converter, the effective duty ratio is not reduced, and the conduction loss from the circulating energy is relatively low by resetting the secondary current during Mode 3 [25], [26].

Extremely good results were obtained with the speed observer presented in [6].

The speed observer idea presented in [6] is based on extending the order of the Luenberger observer [27] with a simple model of EMFwhere \${\mmb \xi} = [\matrix{\xi_{\alpha} & \xi_{\beta}}]^{{\rm T}}\$, \$\omega_{r}\$ is the motor mechanical speed, \$\Psi_{r}\$ is the rotor flux:\${\mmb \psi} = [\matrix{\psi_{\alpha} & \psi_{\beta}}]^{{\rm T}}\$, and \$\alpha\beta\$ denotes the stationary frame of references.
Hence, an additional state equation is used [6] where \$\tau\$ is the time in per unit system.
In [6], the EMF is the observer disturbance, which is estimated in pure integrators.

context.text: Such application was previously presented in the authors’ papers [22] and [23].
In [22], the used observers’ structure was explained, and the model of the mechanical system was presented.
Contrary to [22] and [23], a speed observer with an exact model of motor electromotive forces (EMFs) [28] is used in this paper.
A schematic diagram of the HST bogie transmission system was presented in [22] and [23].
The parameters of the motor, which appear in simulation and experiments, are normalized in per unit [6], [22], [23], [26], [28], [30].
The mechanical part of the system was reduced to a two-mass system [22], [23].
Other data were presented in [22] and [23].
In [30], the simplified dynamic equations for EMF disturbances were proposed and used for diagnostic purposes in [22] and [23] .
The block and I/O schemes of the observer were presented in [22] and [23].
It is also better than the results obtained with the previous version of the traction motor speed observer [22], [23].
In [22], the experimental test of the speed observer in the whole train speed range was presented.
For sensorless control of the drive, the difference between the speed observers from [22] and [23] and the speed observer presented in this paper is not noticeable.
Other results of the LTO were presented in [22] and [23].
The mechanical speed of the motor comes from the used gear ratio (1.97), wheel diameter (0.885 m), and the motor pole number (six) [22].
Other tests were provided for higher train speed but for a reason of lower switching frequency of the inverter transistors the motor current was seriously distorted [22].
Therefore, the analysis of the motor load torque should be divided into two methods:online and offline [22], [23].

context.text: Contrary to [22] and [23], a speed observer with an exact model of motor electromotive forces (EMFs) [28] is used in this paper.
The parameters of the motor, which appear in simulation and experiments, are normalized in per unit [6], [22], [23], [26], [28], [30].
In this paper, a newer version of the observer [28] was implemented.

The equations of the speed observer are [28] where ∧ denotes the calculated value; \${\bf i}_{s}\$ and \${\bf u}_{s}^{\rm com}\$ are the stator current and commanded stator voltages, respectively; \$S_{b}\$ is the observer stabilizing component; \$S_{bF}\$ is the \$S_{b}\$ filtered value; \$a_{1} = -(R_{s}L_{r}^{2} + R_{r}L_{m}^{2})/(L_{r}w_{\sigma})\$; \$a_{2} = R_{r}L_{m}/(L_{r}w_{\sigma})\$; \$a_{3} = L_{m}/w_{\sigma}\$; \$a_{4} = L_{r}/w_{\sigma}\$; \$w_{\sigma} = L_{r}L_{s} - L_{m}^{2}\$; \$k_{1}\$, \$k_{2}\$, \$k_{3}\$, and \$k_{4}\$ are the observer gains; and \$k_{fo}\$ is the \$S_{b}\$ low-pass filter coefficient.

Contrary to [28], the component related to \$d\mathhat{\omega}_{r}/d\tau\$ observer was omitted, assuming that, for a small step of the observer calculation, this component is close to zero in the high-inertia train system.

context.text: With respect to conference papers [22]–[24], where we proposed preliminary designs of the aforementioned blocks, this paper presents: 1) a deep insight on the design choices; 2) new implementation results related to technologies suitable for automotive systems, being [22], [24] limited to rad-tolerant or high-cost technologies mainly for aerospace systems; and 3) a detailed verification phase at simulation and emulation levels, not present in [22]–[24], with experimental results ensuring exhaustive testing of the hardware blocks.

In this paper, differently from [22] and [24], the very high speed integrated circuit hardware description language (VHDL) code is partitioned in three blocks: LVDS drivers for data (Din/Dout) and strobe (Sin/Sout) signals, SpW Codec, and SpW I/O wrapper.

With respect to [22] and [24], besides HDL test benches, this paper also exploits a coverage-driven verification strategy based on Specman Verification Components as conformance testers for the AHB host bus and the SpW links.
Owing to this approach, the code and functional coverage of the IPs grows up to 100%, while a value of 91% was reached in [22] and [24] using HDL test benches.

context.text: Since one of the subsystems enjoy a strong stability property [1], this decomposition motivates a cascaded-control loop structure.

Furthermore, the system \$(x_{3})\$ with control input \$u\$ and disturbance input \$x_{4}\$ is output strictly passive (see [1]), i.e., it verifies a strong stability property that ensures convergence to equilibrium \$x_{3}^{\ast}\$ for all \$x_{4}\$, the latter being the only interconnection of \$(x_{3})\$ with the system \$(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{4})^{\top}\$.
On the other hand, the controller of the inner loop generates the real control input \$u\$ that ensures the convergence of \$y_{3}\$ to \$y_{3}^{\ast}\$ (see [1] for more details).

A passivity-based stability study is presented in [1], where a general methodology is proposed to tune the gains of a given controller that, exploiting the passivity property, ensures stability of the closed loop.
Toward this end, the recent theoretical results of [1] will be instrumental for the controller tuning procedure.

context.text: The fuel cell presents the problem of oxygen starvation when the load changes rapidly [2], [8].
To avoid starvation in this case, the stoechiometry (ratio of the input oxygen flow over the reacted oxygen flow in the cathode) should be maintained around a constant desired value [2], [6].

In the interesting work of [2], it is shown that, for the purpose of air-supply control, it is reasonable to reduce the classical ninth order model of [8] to the fourth order dynamics11To keep the physical meaning of all the signals and constants, we have decided to avoid normalization and rescaling, regrettably, at the price of a more cluttered notation. with the state space vector \$x = [x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, x_{4}]^{\top}\$, where \$x_{1}\$ and \$x_{2}\$ are the oxygen and nitrogen partial pressures in the cathode, respectively, \$x_{3}\$ is the angular speed of the compressor, and \$x_{4}\$ is the air pressure in the supply manifold; \$\xi\$ is the stack current, which is traditionally considered as a measurable disturbance to the system, and \$u\$, which represents the compressor-motor voltage, is the control input.
Further details of this model, including the assumptions that have been made to validate the reduction from the model of nine states described in [8], can be found in [2].
In spite of the reduction proposed in [2], the complexity of the model described previously still hampers the application of model-based nonlinear controller-design techniques.

context.text: As is known, the MILO is a preferred cross-field device specifically designed to generate gigawatt-class single-frequency HPM, which has been investigated extensively for decades [6]–[14].

It is chosen for the following three reasons: 1) MILO operates without external magnetic field, so the total device can be compact; 2) MILO's working frequency is stable and easy to control, as it is principally determined by the SWS; and 3) the intrinsic magnetic insulation property enables MILO to handle high input power of tens of gigawatts [6], so it owns stronger potential to generate higher power microwave.

Such a high-frequency MILO is investigated for the following two considerations: 1) Although MILO has been systematically investigated for a long time, most of them, including the bifrequency MILO, perform in low-frequency bands (L-band to C-band) [5]–[6][10].

The middle seven vanes have inner and outer radii of 3.8 and 4.3 cm, respectively, which are preceded by two vanes with smaller inner radius of 3.6 cm to inhibit a microwave leakage to the pulse-power source [6] and followed by three vanes with tapered inner radii gradually increasing by 0.1 cm to provide a good match of the SWS electric field to that of the output coaxial transmission line [7].

context.text: In the mean time, CO-OFDM has recently been demonstrated for its superior performance in spectral efficiency, receiver sensitivity, and polarization-dispersion resilience [8]–[10], but requires higher implementation complexity compared with direct-detection OFDM (DDO-OFDM) [11]–[13].

CO-OFDM has been considered as a promising alternative pathway toward Tb/s transport that possesses high spectral efficiency, resilience to tributary timing alignment and the channel dispersion [19]–[21]. 100-Gb/s CO-OFDM transmission has also been demonstrated using multi-band OFDM to mitigate DAC/ADC electronic bottleneck [8], [9].
Additionally, to extend from current 100-Gb/s demonstration [8]–[10] to 1-Tb/s presents significant challenges, requiring 10-fold bandwidth expansion.

To optically construct the multi-band CO-OFDM signal using cascaded optical modulators [8] entails 10 times higher drive voltage, or use of the nonlinear fiber which may introduce unacceptable noise to the Tb/s signal.

Another major benefit of using the RFS is that we can adjust the delay of the recirculating loop to an integer number (30 in this experiment) of the OFDM symbol periods, and therefore the neighboring bands not only reside at the correct frequency grids, but are also synchronized in OFDM frame at the transmit, which is a necessary condition for orthogonal-band-multiplexing (OBM) [8].
We have proposed orthogonal-band-multiplexing (OBM) scheme to sub-band the OFDM at the system level [8].
This satisfies the orthogonal-band condition, or in essence, the 1-Tb/s signal is an orthogonal-band-multiplexed OFDM (OBM-OFDM) signal discussed in [8].
The signal is coupled out from the loop and received with a polarization diversity detectors [8]–[10] comprising of a polarization beam splitter, two optical hybrids and four balanced receivers.

The 2×2 MIMO-OFDM signal processing involves [8], [9] (1) FFT window synchronization using Schmidl format to identify the start of the OFDM frame, (2) software estimation and compensation of the frequency offset, (3) channel estimation in terms of Jones vector and Jones Matrix, (4) phase estimation for each OFDM symbol, and (5) constellation construction for each carrier and BER computation.
The antialias filter is critical for OBM-OFDM implementation [8].
The OSNR required for a BER of \$10^{-3}\$ is 27.0 dB, which is about 11.3 dB higher than 107 Gb/s we measured in [8].

For the longest transoceanic systems (\${>}10\ 000\$ km and based on direct detection [60], [70], [71]), whilst the achieved ISDs are usually modest, below 1 b/s/Hz, the results closely approach the Shannon limit.

In these papers, the dispersion maps were optimised to minimize the impact of optical non-linearity; this was achieved in various ways: by removing all dispersion compensation from the system [70]; by combining multiple fibre types within the transmission span with different properties [71] or by destroying quasi-phase matching [43], [44] by carefully balancing broadband dispersion compensation (fibre based) and using a periodic group delay compensation device [60].

In addition, these results partially benefited from a degree of non-linearity compensation, either through the use of guiding filters to combat intra-channel self-phase modulation [60], [72], or via midspan spectral inversion [62], [70].

In the few cases where this gap appears to have been closed, the experiments mitigated the fibre non-linearity [60], [70] or employed larger effective area fibre (note that the reference calculations assumed a fixed value of these parameters) [71], [77].

context.text: Previous research on space vector techniques of CSCs can be summarized as two categories: one is adopted from SVM methods of matrix converters [12] or voltage source converters (VSCs) [13], and the other is direct CSC SVM method based on CSC vectors and various vector sequences [14]–[18][19].
[18] investigate the magnitudes of lower-order harmonics (fifth and seventh) of difference vector sequences and combine two sequences to achieve a better harmonic performance.
Similar to the SVM schemes for VSCs, all the vector sequences available for CSCs can be divided into two categories: triangle carrier based and sawtooth carrier based [18].

Among all the sawtooth-carrier-based sequences in [18], the three-segment sequence \$\to {\buildrel{\rightharpoonup}\over{I}}_{n1} \to {\buildrel{\rightharpoonup}\over{I}}_{n2} \to {\buildrel{\rightharpoonup}\over{I}}_{n0}\$ provides the best overall performance and thereby is selected for detailed analysis and implementation in this paper.
To verify the theoretical analysis and simulation waveforms, experiments on a DSP-field-programmable gate array (FPGA)-based controller platform are carried out to generate the MS-SVM gatings [18].

context.text: In the second category, the frequency of a microwave signal can be measured instantaneously over a large bandwidth [7]–[15].
A microwave frequency can be measured by monitoring and comparing two frequency-dependent optical powers [7]–[9] or two frequency-dependent microwave powers [10]–[15].
In [7], the microwave signal with the frequency to be measured is intensity-modulated on two optical carriers.
The technique in [7] was improved by replacing the comb filter with an optical complementary filter pair [8], [9], which simplifies the system since only a single laser source is required.
The measurement errors due to the power fluctuations of the two laser sources existing in the two-wavelength system [7] were completely eliminated.

context.text: In the second category, the frequency of a microwave signal can be measured instantaneously over a large bandwidth [7]–[10][15].
A microwave frequency can be measured by monitoring and comparing two frequency-dependent optical powers [7]–[9] or two frequency-dependent microwave powers [10]–[15].

The frequency of a microwave signal can also be measured by comparing the microwave powers of the signal that travels in two channels that experience different dispersion-induced power penalties [10], [11].

When the intensity-modulated signals pass through a dispersive element, such as a multichannel chirped fiber Bragg grating (MCFBG) [10] or a dispersive fiber [11], the two intensity-modulated signals would experience different chromatic dispersions, leading to different power penalties.
The approaches based on microwave power monitoring in [10], [11] are advantageous due to their simple architectures, such as the use of a single modulator.
On the other hand, the approaches in [10], [11] has a major limitation: the measurement range is limited.
It is different from the approaches in [10], [11], where a large dispersion difference is usually required to ensure a large measurement range.

context.text: In the second category, the frequency of a microwave signal can be measured instantaneously over a large bandwidth [7]–[11][15].
A microwave frequency can be measured by monitoring and comparing two frequency-dependent optical powers [7]–[9] or two frequency-dependent microwave powers [10]–[11][15].

The frequency of a microwave signal can also be measured by comparing the microwave powers of the signal that travels in two channels that experience different dispersion-induced power penalties [10], [11].

When the intensity-modulated signals pass through a dispersive element, such as a multichannel chirped fiber Bragg grating (MCFBG) [10] or a dispersive fiber [11], the two intensity-modulated signals would experience different chromatic dispersions, leading to different power penalties.
The measurement range and resolution can be adjusted by simply adjusting the wavelength spacing of the two laser sources or the dispersion of the dispersive element [11].
The approaches based on microwave power monitoring in [10], [11] are advantageous due to their simple architectures, such as the use of a single modulator.
On the other hand, the approaches in [10], [11] has a major limitation: the measurement range is limited.
It is different from the approaches in [10], [11], where a large dispersion difference is usually required to ensure a large measurement range.
For the system proposed in [11], the wavelengths of the two laser sources are 1470 and 1600nm and the dispersive element is a 20-km single-mode fiber.

context.text: We consider multichannel signal detection in the presence of spatially and temporally colored disturbance, a problem also known as space-time adaptive processing (STAP) in radars [1].

The problem of interest is to detect a \$JN\times\$1 multichannel signal \${\bf s}\$ with unknown amplitude \$\alpha\$ in the presence of spatially and temporally correlated disturbance (e.g., [1]) where \$J\$ denotes the number of spatial channels and \$N\$ the number of temporal observations (i.e., snapshots).

A standard assumption in STAP detection (e.g., [1]–[8]) is that the disturbance signals \${\{{\bf d}_{k}\}}_{k=0}^{K}\$ are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) with distribution \${\cal CN}({\bf 0},{\bf R})\$, where \${\bf R}\$ is the unknown space-time covariance matrix.

context.text: This has led to recent development of STAP techniques with reduced training requirement, including partially adaptive or reduced-rank detection (e.g., [7]–[11]), parametric STAP detection [12]–[22], and others.
Specifically, the parametric adaptive matched filter (PAMF) [12], one of the first in this class, models the disturbance signal as a parametric multichannel autoregressive (AR) process.

The parametric STAP detectors [12], [14]–[16] further assume that the disturbance signal \${\bf d}_{k}(n)\$, \$k=0,\ldots,K\$, can be modeled as a \$J\$-channel \${\rm AR}(P)\$ process where \$\{{\bf A}^{H}(i)\}_{i=1}^{P}\$ denotes the unknown \$J\times J\$ AR coefficient matrices and \${\mmb\varepsilon}_{k}(n)\$ denotes the \$J\times 1\$ spatial noise vectors that are assumed to be temporally white but spatially colored Gaussian noise \${\mmb\varepsilon}_{k}(n)\sim{\cal CN}({\bf 0},{\bf Q})\$, where \${\bf Q}\$ denotes the unknown \$J\times J\$ spatial covariance matrix.

The multichannel AR process has been found to be an effective tool to model real-world airborne radar clutter for STAP detection [14], [23], [24].

This is different from other parametric STAP detectors (e.g., [14] and [15]), which have a clear interpretation of sequential temporal and spatial whitening (see discussions in Section IV for details).

The parametric STAP detectors [12], [14]–[16] further assume that the disturbance signal \${\bf d}_{k}(n)\$, \$k=0,\ldots,K\$, can be modeled as a \$J\$-channel \${\rm AR}(P)\$ process where \$\{{\bf A}^{H}(i)\}_{i=1}^{P}\$ denotes the unknown \$J\times J\$ AR coefficient matrices and \${\mmb\varepsilon}_{k}(n)\$ denotes the \$J\times 1\$ spatial noise vectors that are assumed to be temporally white but spatially colored Gaussian noise \${\mmb\varepsilon}_{k}(n)\sim{\cal CN}({\bf 0},{\bf Q})\$, where \${\bf Q}\$ denotes the unknown \$J\times J\$ spatial covariance matrix.

Recall that a fully adaptive STAP detector such as Kelly’s GLRT [3] performs a joint spatiotemporal whitening across all \$JN\$ dimensions, whereas the parametric Rao or PAMF detector performs successive (as opposed to joint) whitening, i.e., temporal whitening followed by spatial whitening [14], [15].

context.text: This has led to recent development of STAP techniques with reduced training requirement, including partially adaptive or reduced-rank detection (e.g., [7]–[11]), parametric STAP detection [12]–[16][22], and others.
The PAMF detector is shown to be equivalent to a parametric Rao detector in [16].
The parametric generalized likelihood ratio test (GLRT) [16] is a recent addition into the parametric STAP family.
An interesting observation made in [16] is that it is possible to trade range training with the number of pulses within a coherent processing interval (CPI).

In contrast, [16] shows that the clutter statistic can be extracted from the temporal pulses over a CPI; in the extreme case, this can be achieved exclusively from the test signal, without using any range training, provided that the number of pulses is large enough.
An iterative search-based procedure is employed in [16], which is seen to be computationally intensive.
Section II contains the data model and a summary of the original GLRT of [16], where an underlying nonlinear amplitude estimation problem is also highlighted.

The parametric STAP detectors [12], [14]–[16] further assume that the disturbance signal \${\bf d}_{k}(n)\$, \$k=0,\ldots,K\$, can be modeled as a \$J\$-channel \${\rm AR}(P)\$ process where \$\{{\bf A}^{H}(i)\}_{i=1}^{P}\$ denotes the unknown \$J\times J\$ AR coefficient matrices and \${\mmb\varepsilon}_{k}(n)\$ denotes the \$J\times 1\$ spatial noise vectors that are assumed to be temporally white but spatially colored Gaussian noise \${\mmb\varepsilon}_{k}(n)\sim{\cal CN}({\bf 0},{\bf Q})\$, where \${\bf Q}\$ denotes the unknown \$J\times J\$ spatial covariance matrix.
To introduce the necessary notation and also to facilitate comparison, we briefly summarize the parametric GLRT [16] as follows.

Then, the initial estimate is refined through a weighed LS process (see [16] for details).
This corroborates earlier numerical results [16], which shows that the parametric GLRT in general outperforms the parametric Rao when the data available for estimation become very limited.

For both cases, we compare the \${\bf LS}\$ estimator (12), \${\bf AML1}\$ of [16], \${\bf AML2}\$ (27), and the \${\bf ML}\$ estimator (4) initialized by AML1 (this consideration is motivated by the fact that AML1 provides the best known initial estimate prior to this work).

Also included in the comparison are the asymptotic result provided by the parametric GLRT (see [16]) and the ideal MF, which assumes exact knowledge of \${\bf R}\$ and, therefore, cannot be used in practice but offers a baseline for comparison.
In general, for low-order AR models, the parametric GLRT can provide good detection performance (e.g., within 3 dB from the MF bound) if \$N/J>5\$ [16].

context.text: Recently, SC-IFDE without CP has been investigated in [4]–[6], [9], in which the feedbacks from the decoder are used to restore the effect due to the removal of CP.
As shown in Fig. 1, the iterative receiver of SC-IFDE without CP consists of a channel estimator, a frequency domain equalizer, and a soft-in soft-out decoder, working iteratively [4]–[6], [9].

A low-complexity frequency domain channel estimator has been proposed in [6] for SC-IFDE without CP, where Kalman-filtering is performed on a per-tone basis by ignoring the correlation among different tones, followed by an across-tone refinement process, and the time correlation of the channel is exploited by a unidirectional recursion.

To overcome this problem, approximate message updating rules are developed to make the proposed channel estimation approach with similar complexity as that in [6], but significantly outperforms the latter as demonstrated by simulation results.

As in [6], the residual inter-segment interference is assumed to be ignored, and then we have the following model  where “*” denotes the linear convolution operation, \${\mbi{n}}_{k}\$ denotes the additive Gaussian noise with variance \$2 \sigma ^{2} {\mbi{I}}\$, \${\mbi{r}}_{k} ^{\prime}\$ is the counterpart of \${\mbi{r}}_{k}\$ after the inter-segment interference cancellation.

Note that \${\mbi{x}}_{k}= {\mbi{p}}_{k}+ {\mbi{s}}_{k}\$ consists of both the pilot component \${\mbi{p}}_{k}\$ and the data component \${\mbi{s}}_{k}=\left [s_{k,0}, \ldots, s_{k,M-1}\right ]^{T}\$, and the means and variances of \$\{s_{k,m}\}\$ 22Note that \$\{s_{k,m}\}\$ are approximately statistically independent of each other due to the use of the interleaver. (i.e., \$\{E(s_{k,m})\}\$ and \$\{V(s_{k,m})\}\$) are available from the output of the decoder [4]–[6], [9].

In the following, we extend ththe unidirectional Kalman-filtering based approach in [6] to bidirectional processing and efficiently estimate each \${\mbi{h}}_{k}\$ based on all the observation vectors \$\{{\mbi{y}}_{j}, j=0, 1, \ldots, K-1\}\$ by using the GMP technique [10] operating in an FFG of the linear Gaussian system described by (1), (5) and (6).
This leads to the complexity of the proposed approach \$O(N {\rm log}_{2}N)\$ per building block (i.e., \$O({\rm log}_{2}N)\$ per symbol), which is similar to that in [6].
For comparison, the approach in [6] is used with superimposed training.

It can be seen that, with the \${\rm E_{b}/N_{0}}\$ increasing, all the estimators approach the performance with exact data symbols, and the GMP-based channel estimators with the proposed approximate rules significantly outperform the one in [6].
It can be seen that about 2 dB BER performance gain can be achieved by using any version of the proposed GMP-based approach compared with that using the approach in [6].

context.text: In this letter, we extend the unidirectional frequency domain channel estimation approach to bidirectional processing with the recently developed Gaussian message passing (GMP) technique [10], thereby enhancing the capability of the channel estimator in capturing the channel correlation information, leading to significant performance improvement.

By representing the SC-IFDE system model with a Forney-style factor graph (FFG) [10], channel estimation can be performed through local message computations and exchanges between the basic building blocks in the FFG based on the GMP updating rules in [10].

In the following, we extend ththe unidirectional Kalman-filtering based approach in [6] to bidirectional processing and efficiently estimate each \${\mbi{h}}_{k}\$ based on all the observation vectors \$\{{\mbi{y}}_{j}, j=0, 1, \ldots, K-1\}\$ by using the GMP technique [10] operating in an FFG of the linear Gaussian system described by (1), (5) and (6).
The GMP technique [10] provides a factor graph based signal processing approach for linear systems.

Since the sum-product message updating rules for the basic building blocks preserve Gaussianity, the message passing in the FFG of a linear Gaussian system can be characterized by the updating of mean vectors and covariance matrices (or the inverses of covariance matrices and transformed mean vectors) for the basic building blocks [10].
Through local computations based on the GMP updating rules for the basic building blocks [10], the global information (means and variances) of the variables can be obtained.

Given messages at \$a\$ (i.e., the mean vector \${\mbi{m}}_{a}\$ and the covariance matrix \${\mbi{V}}_{a}\$, which are the a priori mean and variance of \${\mbi{h}}_{k}\$ provided by building block \$k-1\$), based on the GMP updating rules [10], the message at \$b\$ (i.e., the mean vector \${\mbi{m}}_{b}\$ and the covariance matrix \${\mbi{V}}_{b}\$) can be computed as  where the diagonal matrix  is the inverse of the covariance matrix of \${\mbi{c}}_{k}\$ at point \$d\$ in Fig. 3 (see (7) for the definition of \$\beta\$), and  is the transformed mean vector of \${\mbi{c}}_{k}\$.
After the forward and backward recursions, the final estimate of \${{\mbi{h}}_{k}}\$ is obtained by combining its messages in both directions [10].

context.text: To further deduce the complexity of the decoding scheme, in our previous work [20], we proposed a new decoding approach that combines decoding with array processing.
The complexity of this approach was evaluated in [20], and it increases with \$2\sqrt{M}\$, which is considerably lower than that of all traditional schemes.
Unfortunately, in a QO-STBC OFDM system, the decoding method proposed in [20] cannot directly be utilized, as coding here is based on OFDM symbols, which are vectors rather than scalars.

Obviously, the low-complexity decoding method cannot directly be used in this coded OFDM system, since we cannot split up the channel matrix and calculate their null spaces just like what we did in a simple QO-STBC system, as described in [20].
From the results given in (9), we can show that the decoding scheme proposed in [20] can be utilized afterward.

To show how much we can benefit from the proposed decoding method, we include the results on computational complexity comparison between the traditional and proposed schemes in this paper, as shown in Table II [20].

context.text: Recently, a novel cost-effective EDC receiver for on-off keyed (OOK) systems was proposed, which accesses the full optical field with significantly reduced complexity using a single asymmetric Mach–Zehnder interferometer (AMZI) prior to photo-detection [9].

The recovered information allows for full optical-field CD compensation with a dispersive transmission line [9]–[11], feed-forward equalizer [3], or maximum likelihood sequence estimation [12], [13] in the electrical domain.

The intensity and frequency information is used to reconstruct a replica of the optical signal in the radio frequency (RF) range by applying the signals \$V _{\rm A}\$ and \$V _{\rm f}\$ to amplitude and frequency modulators respectively, allowing for subsequent full optical-field compensation using a dispersive transmission line [9].
This is in close agreement to previously simulated performance which indicated a 1 dB \$Q\$-factor degradation at 500km with an 83 km amplifier spacing [9].

context.text: The recovered information allows for full optical-field CD compensation with a dispersive transmission line [9]–[10][11], feed-forward equalizer [3], or maximum likelihood sequence estimation [12], [13] in the electrical domain.

The impact of the noise was further increased by noise amplification mechanisms arising from the division by total received power and low-frequency component amplification in full-field reconstruction [10].
Therefore, we adopted an equivalent implementation using a balanced photo-detector to give \$V _{1}-V _{2}\$ and an additional single photo-detector to obtain \$V _{1}+V _{2}\$ [10], [11].

The generated OOK signal was transmitted over a recirculating loop comprising 124km of field-installed SSMF in the BT Ireland network between Cork City and Clonakilty, County Cork, Ireland, with a signal launch power of approximately 0 dBm per span, at which the fibre nonlinear effect was negligible [10].

In the subsequent offline processing, \$V _{\rm x} (t)\$ (electrical signal from the single photo-detector) was rebiased to allow for the ac coupling of the receiver and to increase the robustness to thermal noise [10], [11].
A Gaussian-shaped high-pass (HP) electrical filter with 1GHz 3dB cutoff frequency was employed (unless otherwise stated) to suppress the effect of low-frequency component amplification [10].

Such noise not only directly degraded the quality of the photodiode outputs but also severely affected full-field reconstruction via the electronic amplification of the signal noise arising from the division by the total received power in phase estimation (see Fig. 2) and low-frequency amplification [10].
The signal was launched into the transmission link of 120 km SSMF per span with 0 dBm [10].
When reducing the sampling rate to 20 Gsamples/s, around 1.2dB and 5 dB OSNR penalties were induced for the fibre length of 480 and 2160 km, respectively [10].

Contributing another series of single-stage inverters with a larger voltage boost ratio to the existing pool of buck–boost inverters, this paper presents a number of diode-assisted VSIs, whose topological layouts use only a single inductive element, similar to those reported in [1] and [2].

For comparison, the Ćuk-derived buck–boost inverter discussed in [1] and [2] is briefly described here, and it is shown in Fig. 1(a) that the inverter uses a voltage boost circuitry to boost its dc input voltage by controlling the conductive duty ratio of switch SW.

Mathematically, by performing state-space averaging, it can easily be shown that the capacitor voltage \$V_{C}\$ and peak ac output voltage \$\hat v\$ of the inverter can explicitly be expressed as [1], [2]  where k refers to the conductive duty ratio of SW, M represents the modulation index commonly linked to traditional inverter control, and 1/(1−k) is defined as the voltage boost factor.

For preliminary illustration and subsequent comparison, Fig. 3(a) shows the SEPIC-derived buck–boost inverter previously proposed in [1] and [2], where inductor L and switch SW in the front-end voltage boost circuitry are noted to swoop their positions, as compared to the Ćuk-derived topology (see Fig. 1).

Nevertheless, the gain in (5) is still higher than that produced by the SEPIC inverter reported in [1] and [2], with its voltage-buck feature preserved and freely tuned by adjusting M and k accordingly.

context.text: Zhao et.al [5] proposed a scheme for tamper-proof of web pages.

Comparing with the existing schemes, our scheme has three characteristics as follows: (1) It can detect the modifications of a web page and locate their locations, meanwhile, it can also identify the types of the modifications; (2) The increment of the file size in this scheme is smaller than the literature [5]; (3) It can avoid the collage attacks.
In this paper, we also use the two kinds of watermarks called word watermark and line watermark which were used in the literature [5].

Table.1 and Table.2 illustrate the statistical result for the file size of watermarked web pages and the increment rate of the web pages'size through using two kinds of generating methods which are mentioned in the literature [5] and this paper.
The comparison in Table.1 and Table.2 can tell us that the increment of file size using the method proposed in this paper is smaller than the method proposed in the literature [5].

context.text: In [10], the authors note that WSN deployments to date can be divided in two categories: environmental monitoring applications (e.g., [15]), designed with low-power operation allowing them to run for long periods, and high-rate, high-fidelity ones running only for a relatively short time.
In general, although WSNs have been used for monitoring civil structures [10], [3],1[3], [7], [22], [4], the combination of requirements we must address is unique.
For instance, the work in [10] uses directional antennas, motivated by the peculiar shape of the target area.
Moreover, the nodes used by [10] cost ~\$600 each, which in our case would make the WSN solution not cost-effective compared to a traditional one.
On the software side, real-world deployments mostly feature ad-hoc implementations [10], [13], [22], which make very difficult extending or adapting their functionality to different scenarios.

We are neither confirming with a proof-of-concept “the eventual ability to cover a large civil structure with low-cost wireless sensors” [3] nor we are validating already known models using WSNs instead of conventional systems [10].
Some deployments [10] use the flash chip on the mote as a temporary buffer.

context.text:
The following assumptions are introduced to characterize the no-wait flow shop problem [10]:

•Job operation times are deterministic and known in advance
•An operation once started on a machine cannot be interrupted before completion (no pre-emption)
•Jobs consist of a strictly ordered sequence of operations
•The same job sequence is assumed for each job, but machine skipping is allowed
•Once a job is started, it must be processed until completion without any interruption either on or between machines
.

context.text: This study was originally motivated by learning from imbalanced data, expanding on the study in [19], which examined several evaluation functions to evolve the weights of ANNs using Genetic Algorithms (GAs), three of which were designed to remove the bias that error-based approaches have towards the major class(es).
Thus, they convert the multi-objective evaluation into a single-objective function, which then shares the same issue as shown in [19].

Since the error of each class is not treated as separate objectives, this is similar to a general error measure examined in [19], and, therefore, will have the same issue of being biased towards the major class(es) and not offering solutions with different performance trade-offs.
In the first phase, a MOGA is used to evolve (train) a set of ANNs by optimising their weights, essentially an extension of [19] to multiple objectives.
The core of the real-coded MOGA remains much the same as the GA used in [19]; adopting tournament selection [24], Gaussian mutation [25] and BLX-\$\alpha\$ crossover [26].

From the experimental results shown in Table 1 and Table 2, we can see that the proposed method gets higher average forecasting accuracy rates than the existing methods [1], [2], [4], [5], [8], [10] due to the fact that the proposed method gets smaller mean square errors than the methods presented in [1], [2], [4], [5], [8] and [10].

references.text: Juhao Li et al., OECC 2008, Sydney, TuA-3

context.text: Moreover, we have proposed that MIMO DFE can be used to equalize the interferences among the branch signals after balanced-photodiode detection (BPD) or single-photodiode detection (SPD) for the DQPSK signal [5], and that electrical joint equalization helps to combat with PMD-induced transmission impairments in PDM systems [6].

In comparison to the simulation results in [6], we can see that jointly processing all the branch signals for both PDM channels helps combat with the interference between the two PDM channels and the 8-i-4-o DFE after SPD performs better than the 4-i-4-o DFE after BPD.

context.text: In fact its functionality includes image acquisition (it can grab an image in a grey scale format, since the texture is of primary interest); feature extraction and preprocessing (data normalization, de-correlation of the feature vectors and dimensionality reduction with PCA and ANOVA); feature classification with neural network (which is trained with our GLPτS genetic low-discrepancy search method [9], when performing supervised learning); and finally, system test and validation and output of the results of the recognition and classification.
Our genetic low-discrepancy search method \$GLP {}_{\tau}S\$ [9] is used for the minimization of the objective function (2).

In this section we briefly introduce our hybrid metaheuristic method, called Genetic \$LP_{\tau}\$ and Neider-Mead Simplex Search \$(GLP{}_{\tau}S)\$[9], which combines the advantages of the \$LP{}_{\tau}O\$ method [19] with the effectiveness of genetic algorithms (GA), during the early stages of the search, and the local improvement abilities of the Simplex search method [9], when a solution is found.

We further improved the hybrid method in [9], in order to be able to handle efficiently problems of higher than 20 dimensions, by incorporating evolutionary strategy and genetic operators for finding promising regions at the early stages of the exploration of the searched hyperspace.

Also, we didn't use random points for the initial population (as in the conventional GA), but adopted uniformly distributed \$LP_{\tau}\$ points (detailed description of the method can be found in [9]).

context.text: To further improve the spectral usage of a transmission link, an AMOOFDM modem using subcarrier modulation (AMOOFDM-SCM) has been proposed [2], which consists of two parallel conventional AMOOFDM modems that produce two real-valued double sideband (DSB) SCM subcarriers with one operating at the baseband and the other being modulated onto an intermediate radio frequency (RF) carrier.

For MMF-based intensity modulation and direct detection (IMDD) transmission links, when compared with AMOOFDM, AMOOFDM-SCM not only doubles the signal transmission capacity versus reach performance, but also considerably relaxes the minimum requirement on key components involved in the AMOOFDM-SCM modems [2].

In all the AMOOFDM-SCM transmitters reported previously [2],[3], at the input of the IFFT operation, AMOOFDM subcarriers, which consist of a total number of 2N parallel data including both the encoded original data and its conjugate counterpart, are arranged to satisfy the Hermitian symmetry.

For short transmission distances of, say <20km, almost no performance difference among all the three RS modem designs is observed in Fig. 2, this is because of the existence of much less pronounced cross-talk effect owing to short transmission distances [2],[3].

references.text: X. Zheng, J. L. Wei and J. M. Tang, Opt. Express. vol.16, no.25, pp. 20427-20440, 2008.
references.title: Opt. Express

context.text: For SMF-based IMDD transmission links, the cross-talk effect induced by beating among different subcarriers of various types upon direct detection in receivers is a dominant factor limiting the maximum achievable AMOOFDM-SCM performance [3].
To mitigate such an effect, three AMOOFDM-SCM schemes, known as AMOOFDM-SCM scheme I, II and III, have been proposed for different application scenarios [3].

The simplified modem designs not only support transmission performances identical to those presented in [3] without compromising system flexibility and robustness to variations in transmission link characteristics, but also offer valuable input/output reconfigurability.

In all the AMOOFDM-SCM transmitters reported previously [2],[3], at the input of the IFFT operation, AMOOFDM subcarriers, which consist of a total number of 2N parallel data including both the encoded original data and its conjugate counterpart, are arranged to satisfy the Hermitian symmetry.

To reduce the subcarrier × subcarrier beating-induced cross-talk effect, a single sideband (SSB) modulation [3] is applied to \$A_{DSB1}(t)\$ and \$A_{DSB2}(t)\$ to generate real-valued SSB SCM subcarriers, \$S_{SSB1}(t)\$ and \$S_{SSB2}(t)\$ After that, an intensity modulator is driven directly by \$S_{{\rm e}}(t)=S_{SSB1}(t)+S_{SSB2}(t)+I_{dc}\$ to generate optical signal coupled into a SMF link.

For short transmission distances of, say <20km, almost no performance difference among all the three RS modem designs is observed in Fig. 2, this is because of the existence of much less pronounced cross-talk effect owing to short transmission distances [2],[3].

This arises due to the use of spectral gaps [3] in RS II and III, which distinguishes the SCM subcarriers locating at low RF frequencies from the unwanted beating products occurring in the vicinity of the optical carrier.

context.text:
We first consider a variation of the standard “four-step” hierarchical FFT algorithm [23]:

1)
Treating \$A\$ as \$N_{\alpha}\times N_{\beta}\$ array (row-major), perform \$N_{\alpha}\$ FFTs of size \$N_{\beta}\$ along the columns.
2)
Multiply each element \$A_{\rm ij}\$ in the array with twiddle factors \$\omega=e^{\pm 2\pi ij/N}\$ (— for a forward transform, \$+\$ for the inverse).
3)
Perform \$N_{\beta}\$ FFTs of size \$N_{\alpha}\$ along the rows.
4)
Transpose \$A\$ from \$N_{\alpha}\times N_{\beta}\$ to \$N_{\beta}\times N_{\alpha}\$
.

context.text: Our histogram-based parallel coordinates approach extends the work of Novotný and Hauser [10], who proposed using binned parallel coordinates as an output-oriented (rendering) approach.

The “sweet spot” thus appears to be between 1 and 4 billion atoms per CU, where we measure consistent floating-point rates over 22 TFlop/s per CU, and iteration times that are quite reasonable for production runs, a few seconds per timestep. (Although the total amount of memory available on Roadrunner is comparable to the IBM/LLNL BlueGene/L platform, where we have demonstrated scalable performance up to 320 billion atoms [7], we have gladly sacrificed memory for improved performance in our Roadrunner redesign, since in practice MD simulations are always bound by computation time, not memory.)

context.text: Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations [8] integrate the classical equations of motion for a collection of atoms interacting via some prescribed analytic or tabulated interatomic potential energy function.

Since the invention of MD simulations a half-century ago, improvements in computational speed, efficient potential functions that are able to describe metallic solids (subsection 3.1), and computational algorithms ([8] and subsection 3.2) have contributed to progress in fundamental material science.
Although highly simplified, it has provided a great deal of insight into fundamental statistical mechanics [8], materials science [14], and fluid dynamics [20] issues.

It is pretty clear that the storage of all floating point information in double precision is probably overkill, but on the other hand using exclusively single precision has been shown to increase fluctuations of quantities such as the total energy of the system, and therefore may result in a non-converged result that can be misleading in terms of its physical interpretation [8].
Another parameter that plays a significant role in reducing the precision of floating point data is the applied timestep, which is used to discretize the equations of motion [8], [30].

To compare our performance against earlier results, we utilize a standard Lennard-Jones benchmark problem [3]–[7] in which the sample is set up in a face-centered-cubic (fcc) crystal lattice, at a density \$(0.8442 \ {\rm atoms }/{\rm s}^{3})\$ corresponding to the triple point (where gas, liquid, and solid phases coexist), but at an elevated temperature (0.9 instead of 0.687 in reduced Lennard-Jones units [8]).

context.text: In the study of two-dimensional (2-D) codes for optical code-division multiple access (O-CDMA), it is well known that larger code cardinality can be achieved by relaxing the maximum cross-correlation value \$({\rm i}.{\rm e}., \lambda_{c})\$ at the expense of code performance [1]–[3][4].

For example, the cardinalities of the \$\lambda_{c}=1\$ carrier-hopping prime codes (CHPCs) [3] and the \$\lambda_{c}=2\$ quadratic-congruence CHPCs (QC-CHPCs) [4] can be improved by solely increasing the code length without changing their \$\lambda_{c}\$.

With the use of the MLPCs in conventional on-off-keying O-CDMA, the hit probabilities [3], [4] are given by \${\sum}_{j=0}^{n}q_{n,j}=1\$ and \${\sum}^{n}_{j=0}jq_{n,j}=w^{2}/(2wP^{k})\$, where \$q_{n,j}\$ denotes the probability of getting \$j\$ hits in a time slot, out of the maximum cross-correlation function of \$\lambda_{c}=n\$.

references.text: C.-Y. Chang, G.-C. Yang, and W.C. Kwong, "Wavelength-time codes with maximum cross-correlation function of two for multicode-keying optical CDMA," J. Lightw. Technol., vol. 24, no. 3, pp. 1093-1100, Mar. 2006.
references.title: Wavelength-time codes with maximum cross-correlation function of two for multicode-keying optical CDMA

context.text: In the study of two-dimensional (2-D) codes for optical code-division multiple access (O-CDMA), it is well known that larger code cardinality can be achieved by relaxing the maximum cross-correlation value \$({\rm i}.{\rm e}., \lambda_{c})\$ at the expense of code performance [1]–[4].

For example, the cardinalities of the \$\lambda_{c}=1\$ carrier-hopping prime codes (CHPCs) [3] and the \$\lambda_{c}=2\$ quadratic-congruence CHPCs (QC-CHPCs) [4] can be improved by solely increasing the code length without changing their \$\lambda_{c}\$.

With the use of the MLPCs in conventional on-off-keying O-CDMA, the hit probabilities [3], [4] are given by \${\sum}_{j=0}^{n}q_{n,j}=1\$ and \${\sum}^{n}_{j=0}jq_{n,j}=w^{2}/(2wP^{k})\$, where \$q_{n,j}\$ denotes the probability of getting \$j\$ hits in a time slot, out of the maximum cross-correlation function of \$\lambda_{c}=n\$.

context.text: The ONR initiated effort has produced a communication scheme called Power Electronics System Network (PESNet) [7]–[8] [9] [10].
The PESNet version 2.2 is introduced in [10].
There are also other changes compared with version 1.2 [10]; the major improvements are the adjustable packet size and the support for asynchronous data transfer.
The resolution of the synchronization in PESNet is directly fixed to the data frame structure, and for some applications, this may be too low [10].
The 8B/10B encoding has also been proposed for the future version of PESNet, instead of 4B/5B encoding [10].

context.text:
The main advantages of the GA over other conventional optimization techniques are summarized as follows [9]–[12][13]:

1)
GA technique uses a population of trials representing possible solutions of the problem, not a single point.
Details of these rules are listed in [10], [12].
The described genetic algorithm that was applied successfully in [12] is used as a method of tuning PI controller parameters of the position controller in this paper.

Again if the objective function is minimum when \${\rm n}={\rm m}\$ then apply the following formula [10], [12] to calculate the crossover individuals (new modified \${\rm K}_{{\rm p}}({\rm n})\$ and \${\rm K}_{{\rm i}}({\rm n})\$ that will be used in the next generation for \${\rm n}=1\$ to \${\rm n}=10\$ and \${\rm n}\neq {\rm m})\$.
Design of the conventional PI controllers is carried out using Ziegler-Nichols method [12], [14].

context.text: Because Roadrunner—and Roadrunner's form of hybrid computing—is still in its infancy, there are virtually no high-level languages or application programming interfaces (APIs) that support it. (IBM's ALF library [11] does support hybrid execution within a node but not across nodes.) Consequently, all of the initial applications that have targeted hybrid execution on Roadrunner utilize low-level communication mechanisms: MFC I/O [12] for intra-socket communication among SPEs (over the Element Interconnect Bus) and between the SPEs and the PPE, DaCS [13] for communication within a node between a PPE and an Opteron, and MPI [14] for internode communication.

context.text: Based on the economy of scale and advanced web and networking technologies, cloud operators such as Amazon [7] and Google [8] aim to offer researchers as many resources as they need when they need them for as long as they need them.

references.text: Actually, the cell 2ni is restored to contain a starting-condition content, which is a special "indicate the present instruction-address and jump" instruction, to facilitate the calculation of the number L. The cell (2ni+1) needs no clearing, since its content will be written over by the new jump-back instruction in the next modification.

This is especially important in cases Where the control in the computer works with the time-sharing principle of advance preparatory interpretation of instructions. Otherwise, spurious display may occur through changes of the IC content in case of jumps, etc.
This structure form has, furthermore, the advantage that the whole matrix may be divided into smaller identical subunits, so that the printed-circuit technique can be used.

This is because the "start lamp-display" pulse cannot be made longer than the shortest probable interval between the start of an instruction execution and the subsequent changing (counting-up-by-one, etc.) of the IC content.

Since it is also not necessary for these flip-flops to have very fast rise and fall times, they can be built with aged tubes rejected from the computer (if it is one with tubes) because of reduced cathode emission.

context.text: The problem space can be partitioned into four main categories (Figure 1). 1) At the low end of the spectrum (low number of tasks and small input size), we have tightly coupled MPI applications (white). 2) As the data size increases, we move into the analytics category, such as data mining and analysis (blue); MapReduce [4] is an example for this category. 3) Keeping data size modest, but increasing the number of tasks moves us into the loosely coupled applications involving many tasks (yellow); Swift/Falkon [5], [6] and Pegasus/DAGMan [7] are examples of this category. 4) Finally, the combination of both many tasks and large datasets moves us into the data-intensive many task computing category (green); examples of this category are Swift/Falkon and data diffusion [8], Dryad [9], and Sawzall [10].

In the world of high throughput computing, systems such as Condor [13], MapReduce [4], Hadoop [24], and BOINC [25] have used highly distributed pools of processors, but the focus of these systems has not been on single highly parallel machines such as those we focus on here.

context.text: The problem space can be partitioned into four main categories (Figure 1). 1) At the low end of the spectrum (low number of tasks and small input size), we have tightly coupled MPI applications (white). 2) As the data size increases, we move into the analytics category, such as data mining and analysis (blue); MapReduce [4] is an example for this category. 3) Keeping data size modest, but increasing the number of tasks moves us into the loosely coupled applications involving many tasks (yellow); Swift/Falkon [5], [6] and Pegasus/DAGMan [7] are examples of this category. 4) Finally, the combination of both many tasks and large datasets moves us into the data-intensive many task computing category (green); examples of this category are Swift/Falkon and data diffusion [8], Dryad [9], and Sawzall [10].
We validate our hypothesis by testing and measuring two systems, Swift [5], [14] and Falkon [6], which have been used to execute large-scale loosely coupled applications on clusters and Grids.
To harness a wide array of loosely coupled applications that have already been implemented and executed in clusters and grids, we build on the Swift [5], [36] and Falkon [6] systems.
